questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You need to implement Local Media Optimization for Direct Routing users at a site.
Users at the site frequently perform the following actions:
✑ Park calls.
✑ Place calls on hold.
✑ Transfer calls to other users.
✑ Escalate calls to conference calls.
Which action will be affected by implementing Local Media Optimization?

discussion.content:
Correct answer
Call escalations from 1 to 1 call between internal customers to multiparty call with external customer/resource result in dropped calls

Held call when resumed, call does not disconnect, call works through Proxy SBC but LMO will stop working for this call.

Selected Answer: C
escalation to conf will be affected.
on hold will work but when resumed LMO won't be effective.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
I'm going with C. The article from MS states that both C and D are correct. Maybe it's multiple answers, but this question doesn't line up.

I would also say that A Call park is affected. Because it is hosted in the cloud. In the same link it says:

Voice apps (e.g. Auto Attendant, Call Queue) do not work. 

LMO does not support Voice Apps, as they reside in the cloud and require external connectivity. No workaround for now.
So, the answer should be D? :)
Should be all impacterd according to the LMO known issues article, right? Maybe transfer is ok.

Selected Answer: D
Ms link under Known issues

comments.content:
You need to read more carefully:

When a user parks a call to initiate music on hold (MoH), it is being escalated from 1:1 to a multiparty call by the Call Controller to invoke Media Controller and Media Processor (serving as AVMCU mixer) through which MoH reaches a user who has been put on hold. De-escalation to a 1:1 call after the call resumes never happens as per design. Disable Local Media Optimization on the Direct Routing SBC.

This doesn't seem an issue at all... you will just have audio anchored to media processor after resume. But it will work.

While on the other hand:
Call escalations from 1 to 1 call between internal customers to multiparty call with external customer/resource result in *dropped calls* (AH-AH! THERE YOU GO!)
Work in progress on a fix. Alternatively, disable Local Media Optimization on the Direct Routing SBC.

The other option is that it's a multiple-select questions, so both are good.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
When a user parks a call to initiate music on hold (MoH), it is being escalated from 1:1 to a multiparty call by the Call Controller to invoke Media Controller and Media Processor (serving as AVMCU mixer) through which MoH reaches a user who has been put on hold. De-escalation to a 1:1 call after the call resumes never happens as per design. Disable Local Media Optimization on the Direct Routing SBC.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that uses Direct Routing.
You need to implement Local Media Optimization.
In the Microsoft Teams admin center, you configure the external trusted IP addresses and define the network regions, network sites, and network subnets.
What should you do next?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C seems like the correct answer, based on the link supplied.
isnt it A?
Yes. Correct Answer C.

choices.D: Modify the default emergency calling policy.
choices.C: Assign Session Border Controllers (SBCs) to sites.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You need to implement PSTN connectivity by using Direct Routing.
What are three requirements for the implementation? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: Answer is correct as the question says UDP *SIGNALLING* port - signalling in Teams is over TCP so opening the UDP ports for signalling answer is invalid here - had it been UDP media ports then there would have been an issue.
Signaling port TCP is correct. MS Teams uses 5067 TLS for signaling which is TCP based.
Agreed answers are correct TCP is signaling UDP is Media

anyone who passes this exam, may i know the 55q can pass the exam?
I just faild twice for ms-720 exam,just.....wuhawu

i think the answer should be: C - D - E
it is recommended to open UDP Ports 3478,3479,3480,3481 from Teams Client to TR/MP which are in the Microsoft Global Network, if the UDP is blocked by firewall the TCP will be used.

comments.content: Signaling to Teams is TCP 5061. UDP is mediastream and not signaling.

choices.A: a Session Border Controller (SBC) that uses a hostname in the onmicrosoft.com domain
choices.B: a firewall rule that opens a TCP signaling port to Microsoft Teams
choices.D: a firewall rule that opens a UDP signaling port to Microsoft Teams
choices.C: a public DNS entry that maps the FQDN of the Session Border Controller (SBC) to a public IP address

questions.question_text:
You are planning a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that will use Direct Routing.
You need to allow traffic from Microsoft 365 to a Session Border Controller (SBC).
Which IP address ranges should you allow through the firewall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Is still valid 17.08.2023 -> https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/direct-routing-plan

Selected Answer: C
Its C
40.104.0.0/15, 40.104.0.0/15

Yes its correct. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges?view=o365-worldwide

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You need to create a new call queue to route calls to support agents. The support agents must be able to see their call queue history and the shared transcribed voicemail. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
Solution: You configure the call queue to use a Microsoft 365 group.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: Passed the exam today. This question has been adjusted to assign the call queue to a Teams Channel

comments.content: Thanks Jules - I am taking the exam tomorrow any other tips ?
Hey @ covid_9, I hope you passed the exam. how many questions did you receive from Examtopics? Any tips or any new questions you would like to share? thank you!

discussion.content: By the The channels are created as office365 Group ! so definitely A is the right answer

agree a poorly worded Q and maybe they have replaced groups with Teams Channel

in this context maybe they are testing whether you understand 365 Groups underpin Teams channels

Selected Answer: B
Channel is the right answer
The answer is wrong. You cannot see call queue history unless added to a channel. This only answers part of the question so for me it is NO.
is it possible to see the call queue history if it is assigned to M365 group? i was thinking that is only possible if you assign call queue to a teams channel.

comments.content: I agree. It's a very poorly worded question though. Because of "must minimize the administrative effort" I would also go with B. No because if you use an M365 Group, the voicemails will be delivered by email and not directly in Teams / the Voice Enabled Channel.
